body: # If authoring a script module, the RootModule is the name of your .psm1 file
# Use the New-Guid command to generate a GUID, and copy/paste into the next line
# Minimum PowerShell version supported by this module (optional, recommended)
# Which PowerShell Editions does this module work with? (Core, Desktop)
# Which PowerShell functions are exported from your module? (eg. Get-CoolObject)
# Which PowerShell aliases are exported from your module? (eg. gco)
# Which PowerShell variables are exported from your module? (eg. Fruits, Vegetables)
# PowerShell Gallery: Define your module's metadata
# What keywords represent your PowerShell module? (eg. cloud, tools, framework, vendor)
# What software license is your code being released under? (see https://opensource.org/licenses)
# What is the URL to your project's website?
# What is the URI to a custom icon file for your project? (optional)
# What new features, bug fixes, or deprecated features, are part of this release?
# If your module supports updateable help, what is the URI to the help archive? (optional)
ModuleManifest.description: Basic skeleton for a PowerShell module manifest, complete with PowerShell Gallery metadata.

body: # Defines the values for the resource's Ensure property.
# [DscResource()] indicates the class is a DSC resource.
# A DSC resource must define at least one key property.
# Mandatory indicates the property is required and DSC will guarantee it is set.
# NotConfigurable properties return additional information about the state of the resource.
# For example, a Get() method might return the date a resource was last modified.
# NOTE: These properties are only used by the Get() method and cannot be set in configuration.
# NotConfigurable properties are set in the Get method.
# Return this instance or construct a new instance.
# Sets the desired state of the resource.
# Tests if the resource is in the desired state.

body: # Specifies a path to one or more locations. Unlike the Path parameter, the value of the LiteralPath parameter is
# used exactly as it is typed. No characters are interpreted as wildcards. If the path includes escape characters,
# enclose it in single quotation marks. Single quotation marks tell Windows PowerShell not to interpret any
HelpMessage="Literal path to one or more locations.")]
